SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: So, by this sleight I have deceiv'd them both,
I'm tooke for him I strive to make her loath. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Needes here more witnesses? Ile call up more.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Oh no, here lyes a witnesse gainst my selfe
Sooner beleev'd than all their hired faiths;
Doome me unto my death, onely except
The lingering execution of your looke;
Let me not live tormented in that brow,
I doe confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh I felt no quicke till now.
All witnesses to this were but dead flesh
I was insensible of all but this.
Would I had given my Kingdome so condition'd
That thou hadst nere confessed it.
Now I stand by the deed, see all in Action,
The close conveyance, cunning passages,
The Artfull fetch, the whisperlng close disguising;
The houre, the Banquet, and the baudy Tapers▪
All sticke in mine eye together; yet thou shalt live.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Torment me not with life, it askes but death.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh hadst thou not confest? hadst thou no sleight?
Where was thy cunning there?
I see it now in thy confession.
Thou shalt not dye as long as this is meate,
Thou kill'dst a Bucke which thou thy selfe shalt eate.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Deare sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Here's Deere strucke dead with thy owne hand,
Tis Venison for thy owne tooth, thou know'st the rellish
A dearer place hath beene thy Taster; hoa, Sertorio! Lodovico

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.L: Here sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Drag hence that body, see it quartered streight,
No living wrath can I extend upon't,
Else torments, horrors, Gibbets, rackes and wheeles
Had with a thousand deaths presented him,
Ere he had tasted one; yet thou shalt live.
Heere, take this Taper lighted, kneele, and weepe,
Ile try which is spent first, that of thine eye,
Ile provide foode for thee, thou shalt not dye.
If there be hell for sinnes that men commit,
Marry a strumpet and she keepes the pit. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: I feard this misery long before it came,
My ominous dreames, and fearefull dreadfulnesse
Promis'd this issue long before twas borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Yonder she kneeles, little suspecting me
The neate discoverer of her Venery.
I were full safe had I Roxano's life
Which in this streame I fish for; how now Lady;
So nere the earth suites not a living Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Vnder the earth were safer and farre happier.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: What is't that can drive you to such discomforts▪
To prize your glories at so meane a Rate?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: The trechery of my servants, good my Lord;

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Dare they prove trecherous? most ignoble Vassals,
To the sweete peace of so divine a Mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: I'me sure one Villaine, whom I dearely lov'd,
Of whom my trust had made Election chiefe,
Perfideously betray'd me to the fury
Of my tempestuous unappeased Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Let me but know him, that I may bestow
My service to your Grace upon his heart
And thence deserve a Mistresse like your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Oh me, too soone behold him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Madam, stand by, let him not see the light.

SP.SPEAKER: Rox.
SP.L: Now I expect reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: He dyes were he my kinseman for that guilt,
Though twere as farre to's heart as tis to th' hilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rox.
SP.L: Ha? what was that? there's a reward with a venge∣ance.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Fall villaine, for betraying of thy Lady,
Such things must never creepe about the earth
To poyson thē right use of service— a Trecher!

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: This is some poore revenge, thankes good my Lord,
Into that cave with him from whence he rose
Not long since and betray'd me to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: O villaine, in, and overtake thy soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Here's a perplexed brest, let that warme steele
Performe but the like service upon me,
And live the rarest friend to a Queenes wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Oh pardon me, that were too full of evill,
I threat not Angels though I smite the Devill:
Doubt not your peace, the King will be appeas'd
There Ile bestow my service.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We are pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: As much as comes to nothing; Ile not sue
To urge the King from that he urg'd him to. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Betrayd where I repos'd most trust? oh heaven,
There is no misery, fit match for mine.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Tyrant Sertorio, Lodovico, bringing in Tymethes limbes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: So, bring 'em forward yet, there, there bestow thēm,
Before her eyes lay the divided limbes
Of her desired Paramour; so, y'are welcome,
Lady you see your cheere, fine flesh, course fare,
Sweete was your lust, what can be bitter there?
By heaven, no other food thy taste shall have▪
Till in thy bowels those Corpes finde a grave.
Which to be sure of, come, Ile locke thee safe
From the worlds pitty: hang those quarters up,
The bottome drinkes the worst in pleasures cup. Exeunt omn.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene. 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Oh my Tymethes! truest joy on earth!
Hath thy fate prov'd so flinty? so perverse?
To the sweete spring both of thy youth and hopes?
This was Mazeres spight, that cursed Rivall,
And if I faile not, his owne plot shall shower
Vpon his bosome like a falling Tower.
My worthy Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh, you should have seene us sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Why my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: The quarters of your friend passed by in Triumph,
A sight that had pleas'd you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: villaine to my fathers pleasure,
No friend of mine▪ the sight had pleased me
Had I not like Mazeres, run my hate
Into the sinne before it grew to act;
And kill'd it ere't had knotted▪ 'twas rare servicē,
If your vex'd Majesty conceive it right.
In politicke Mazeres, serving more
In this discovery, his owne vicious malice
Than any true peace that should make you perfect:
Suffering the hatefull treason to be done
He might have stopt in his confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Most certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Good your Majesty bethinke you
In manly temper and considerate blood;
Went he the way of loyalty, or your quiet,
After he saw the courtesies exceed
T'abuse your peace, and trust them with the deed?

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh no, none but a Traytor would have done it.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: For my Lord, weigh't indifferently.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: I doe, I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: What makes it heynous, burthensome, and monstrous,
Fills you with such distractions, breedes such furies
In your incensed breast, but the deede doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Th'intent had beenē sufficient for his death,
And that full satisfaction; but the act —

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Insufferable,
Sertorio! where's Sertorio. Enter Sertorio.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Seeke out Mazeres suddenly, peace Zenarchus
Let me alone to trap him.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: It may prove,
Behold my friend, how I expresse my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh villaine, had he pierc'd him at first sight,
Where I have one griefe, I had mist ten thousand by't.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: I dreampt of some new honours for my late servicē,
And I wondred how he could keepe off so long from my de∣sert,

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Mazeres?

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: My lov'd Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: I am forgetfull
I am in thy debt some dignities Mazeres,
What shift shall we make for thee? thy late service
Is warme still in our memory and deare favour:
Prithee discover to's the manner how
Thou tookest them subtlely.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: I was received into a waiters roome my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Thou wast!

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: And in a vizard helpt to serve the banquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: Saw him conveyd into a Chamber privately.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: And still thou let'st him runne?

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: I let him play my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: I watcht still nere, till her armes claspt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: And there thou let'st him rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Maz.
SP.L: There he was caught my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: So art thou here; drag him to execution he shall dye.
With tortures bove the thought of Tyranny. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: No words are able to expresse my gladnesse,
Tis such a high bornē rapture that the soule
Pertakes it onely.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: My Lord Mazeres led
Vnto his death?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: It proves too true deare Princēsse.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Curst be the mouth that doom'd him, and for ēvēr
Blasted the hand that parts him from his life.
Was there none fit to practise Tyrannie on
But whom our heart elected? misery of love!
I must not live to thinke oft.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Here's my Sister,
I could not bring that newes will please her better,
My newes brings that command over your passions, you must be merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Have you warrant for't Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Yes, strong enough yfaith; here me, Mazeres
By this time is at his everlasting home;
Where ere his body lyes, I strucke the stroake
I wrought a bitter pill that quickely choak'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Oh me, my soule will out, some wine there hoa!

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Wine for our Sister, for the newes is worth it.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lod▪ with wine and Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: It will prove deare to both; so, give it me; now leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Revenge nere brought forth a more happy issue
Than I thinke mine to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: I'mē setting forth Mazeres, here Zenarchus.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Thou art not like this houre, joviall.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: I shall be after this.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: That does't if any,
Wine doth both helpe defects, and causeth many.
Here's to the deed faith of our last revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Dying men Prophesie, faith tis our last end;
Now I must tell you brother, that I hate you,
In that you hive betray'd my lov'd Mazeres.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: What's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: His deede was loyall, his discovery just,
He brought to light a monster and his lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Nay if you grow so strumpet like in your behaviour to me,
Ile quickely coole that insolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Peace, peace,
There is a Champion fights for me unseene,
I neede not feare thy thereats.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Indeed no Harlot
But has her Champion, besides Baud and Varlet; oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Why law you now such geere will nere thrivē with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: I'me sicke of thy society, poyson to mine eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Tis lower in thy brest the poyson lyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: Tis for Mazeres.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Oh you vertuous powers,
What a right strumpet? poyson under love?

SP.SPEAKER: Amp.
SP.L: That man can nere be safe that divides love. She dyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Zen.
SP.L: Nor she be honest can so soone impart,
Oh ware that woman that can shift her heart. Dyes.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene. 2.
DIV3.STAGE: Thunder and lightning. A blazing starre appeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Ha? thunder? and thou marrow melting blast
Quicke winged lightning; and thou blazing starre,
I like not thy prodigious bearded fire;
Thy beames are fatall: ha? behold the Influence
Of all their malice in my childrens mines?
Their states malignant powers have envyde,
And for some hast strucke with their envies dy'd:
Tis omenous; within there?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Here my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Conveigh those bodies a while from my fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Both dead my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Yes, and we safe, our death we neēd lesse fearē,
Vsurpers issue oft proves dangerous,
We depose others, and they poyson us,
I have found it on Records, tis better thus.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter the Old King, Lapirus, Fidelio, Amorpho, all disguised like Pilgrims.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: My Lord, this Castle is but slightly guarded.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis as I hop'd and wish'd; now blesse us heaven,
What horrid and inhumaine spectacle
Is yonder that presents it selfe to sight?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: It seemes three quarters of a man hung up.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: What Tiranny hath beene exercis'd of late? I dare not venture on.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.L: Feare not my Lord, our habits give us safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: Behold, the Tyrant maketh toward us.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Holy, and reverent Pilgrims, welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Bold strangers, by the Tempest beaten in.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Most welcome still, wee are but stewards for such guests as you,
What we possesse is yours, to your wants due,
We are onely rich for your necessities.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: A generous, free, aad charitable minde
Keepes in thy bosome to poore Pilgrims kinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Tis time of day to dine my friends; Sertorio?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: My Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Our food.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Tis ready for your highnesse.

DIV3.STAGE: Lond Musicke. A banquet brought in, and by it a small Table for the Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Sit, pray sit, religious men right welcome
Vnto our Cates. Grave sir I have observ'd
You waste the vertue of your serious eye
Too much on such a worthlesse objects as that is.
A Traytor when he liv'd call'd that his flesh;
Let hang, here's to you, we are the oldest here,
Round let it goe, fēede, if you like your cheere.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Ready my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Sit merry. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Where ere I looke these limbes arē in mine eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: Some wretch on whom he wrought his Tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Hard was his fate to light into his mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Amorp.
SP.L: Peace, he comes.

DIV3.STAGE: Soft Musicke. Enter the Tyrant with the Queene, her haire loose, she makes a Curtsie to the Table. Ser∣torio brings in the flesh with a skull all bloody, they all wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: I perceive strangers more desire to see
An object than the fare before them set;
But since your eyes are serious Suitors growne
I will discourse; what's seene shall now be knowne.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Your bounty every way conquers poore strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: You Creature whom your eyes so often visit
Held mighty sway over our powers and thoughts,
Indeed we were all hers.
Besides her graces, there were all perfections;
Vnlesse she speakes, no musicke: till her wishes
Brought forth a monster, a detested issue
Poysoning the thoughts I held of her.
SP.STAGE: The Old King sends forth Amorpho.
SP.L: She did from her owne ardour undergoe
Adulterous basenesse with my professed foe;
Her lust strangely betray'd, I ready to surprize them,
Set on fire by the abuse, I found his life
Cunningly shifted by her owne deare hand
And far enough convey'd from my revenge:
Vnnaturally she first abus'd my heart,
And then prevented my revenge by Art.
Yet there I left not; though his trunke were cold
My wrath was flaming, and I exercis'd
New vengeance on his carcase; and gave charge
The body should be quarter'd and hung up; twas donē,
This as a pennance I enjoyn'd her to
To taste no other sustenance; no nor dares
Till her loves body be consum'd in hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: The sinne was great, so is the pennance greivous.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Our vow is sign'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: And was he Lydian borne?

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: He was no lesse, sonne to mine Enemie,
A banisht King; Tymethes was his name.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Oh me, my sonne Tymethes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: Passion may spoyle us: sir, we oft have heard
Of that old King his father; and that justly
This Kingdome was by right due to his sway.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: It was, I thinke it was, till we call'd in
By pollicy and force deceiv'd his confidence,
Shew'd him a tricke of warre and turn'd him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Sinnes boast is worse than sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: All's sure, the guards are seiz'd on.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: The Passagē strongly guarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Holy sir, what's he?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: Our brother, a poore Pilgrime, that gives notice
Of a Religious father that attends
To beare us company in our Pilgrimage.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Oh, ho, tis good, tis very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Alas poore Lady, it makes mee weepe to see what food she eates.
I know your mercy will remit this pennance.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Never, our vow's irrevocable, never;
The Letcher must be swallowed rib by rib,
His flesh is sweete, it melts, and goes downe merrily,
Ha? what arē these?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: Speranza.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Villaine, this minute looses thee, thou Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: Pilgrims weare armes? the old King? and Lapirus?
Betrayd? confounded? oh, I must dye forsworne;
Breake vow, bleed Whore, there is my jealousie flownē.
Oh happie man, tis more revenge to me
Then all your aymes, I have kill'd my jealousie.
I have nothing now to care for more than hell
'T had beene if you had strucke me ere she fell.
I had left her to your lust, the thought is bitternesse,
But she first falne; ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Dye cruell murtherous Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Tyr.
SP.L: So, laugh away this breath,
My lust was nere more pleasing than my death. Dyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.L: As full possest as ever, and as rich
In Subjects hearts and voyces; we present thee
The compleat sway of this usurped Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: I am so borne betwixt the violent streames
Of Ioy and passion, I forget my state;
To all our thankes and favours, and what more
We are in debt to all your free consent
We will discharge in happie governement.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter the Old Queene disguised, a Boy with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: The peacefull'st reigne that ever Prince enjoy'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Already a Petition? suitors begin betimes
We are scarce warme in our good fortune yet, what are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Vnworthiest of all the joyes this houre brings forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Our dearest Queene?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Your poore distressed Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Oh let me light upon that constant brest,
And kisse thee till my soule melt on thy lips:
Our Joyes were perfect, stood Tymethes there,
We are old; this Kingdome wants a hopefull heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Your joyes are perfect though he stand not there,
And your wish blest behold a hopefull heire:
Stand not amaz'd, 'tis Manophes.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: How just the Gods are? who in their due time
Returne what they tooke from us.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Happy houre,
Heaven hath not taken all our happinesse;
For though your elder met ill fate, good heaven
Hath thus preserv'd your yonger for your heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Prepare those limbes for honourable buriall,
And noble Nephew all your ill is lost
In your late new borne goodnesse, which we'le reward,
No storme of fate so fierce but time destroyes,
And beates backe miserie with a peale of Joyes.
